figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 058, page 4.

div2.head:
Monday morning...March 11, 1861.
reply of Ex-Secretary Floyd.

div3.p:
Ex-Secretary Floyd has published a reply to the charges of the Morris Investigating Committee, connecting him with the recent Indian Trust Fund defalcation.
He contradicts the assertion that he ever acknowledged to Senator Benjamin that the acceptances on the War Department, given by him to Major Russell & Co., were lihegal; for he never believed they were.
To show that they were legal, he adduces precedents of former Secretaries in various departments of the Government, and shows that during the war with Mexico they were issued to the amount of $20,000,000. Showing the necessity of giving them to the contractors in the case in point, he says:

q.p:
It was plain that they could obtain credit only upon their contract; and the acceptances I gave seemed the only mode available of providing them with the means necessary for their operations.
The house of Russell, Majors and Waddell was universally esteemed throughout the West as inferior to none either in capital, credit or character.
This firm had, by its promptness, efficiency and fairdealing, won the confidence of the Government, in whose service it had been since 1843.
It was, therefore, under the cireumstances, no imprudence even to confide to them the important trust of taking care of their own credit.

At the time the first of the acceptances were given, there was a deficiency of funds to pay for the operations of the Quartermaster's Department, for the fiscal year preceding that of my coming into office; besides which fact, an extraordinary outlay, in advance of appropriations, was necessary for the expedition to Utah; and these first acceptances were given to meet the emergency thus preseuted.
Moreover, trains of these contractors, laden with army supplies, had about that time been destroyed by the Mormons, in respect to which catastrophe the accounting officers of the Government were bound, of course, not only to refuse payment of the transportation money earned, but to withhold also the value of the supplies on hand out of other dues of the contractors, who thus lost not only their earnings, but the value of the goods for which they had receipted, as well as their teams and stock.
This loss, resulting from the act of the public enemy, and justly chargeable upon the Government, could only be made good by Congress.

The President, Mr. Buchanan, was right, and said truly to Mr. Benjamin, that if Mr. Floyd had given these acceptances, they were, no doubt, right and proper.
So they were; they were in strict conformity to law, and they enabled the War Department to ensure the maintenance of the army at points more than a thousand miles beyond the borders of our white settlements with as much certainty and regularity as if they had been stationed in ordinary frontier posts.
And I assert, without contradiction, that such regu larity and certainly, in furnishing supplies of every sort to large forces so remotely posted, at rates so economical and under difficulties so imposing, were never witnessed before in the history of any military movement on the globe.
Mr. Buchanan might well say the transaction was right and proper.

div3.p: The amount of acceptances.

The total earnings of the years 1858, 1859, 1860, and those estimated for 1861, were $5,640,753; which is exclusive of claims of an extraordinary character which Congress alone can allow.
On the other hand, the acceptances which I gave to anticipate these earnings, excluding those which were returned to the Department unused and cancelled, was $5,339,395; or $300,000 less than the earnings.
Thus the amount of the acceptances that were given during the three years is due solely to the unprecedented magnitude of the service performed.
The committee, for sensation purposes, endeavor to produce the impression that these acceptances were all outstanding atone time, and are still outstanding, liable to come against the Government for payment.
As well might they have collected up all the bonds which the Government had issued from its beginning, including all that had been paid and cancelled, and declared the grand total to be the debt of the nation.-- They had abundant proof before them that these acceptances, for which the Government had at all times security in the amounts accruing to the contractors, were all paid by them as they matured until September last; and they confess, in another part of their report that, deducting those which were put into the hands of Balley by Russell, and which I immediately cancelled on discovering the perversion, there were but $575,000 of them outstanding known to the department; which would of course receive notice of them all.-- (Deducting $870,000 from $1,445,000, leaves $575,000.) The committee were bound to admit this fact; but they cover up the admission in disingenuous verbiage which conceals it from the public.
The committee could also have learned, if they had pursued their inquiries far enough to embrace the whole truth, that the outstanding acceptances had been provided by the contractors in an assignment of property believed to be ample for their protection, and that no ultimate loss to the Government is likely to ensue on account of them-- Indeed, that a large portion of them had been secured by double assignments.
Thus the committee's magnificent bubble of six or seven millions of acceptances, likely to fall upon the Government, collapses under the touch of truth to less than six hundred thousand, secured by assignment of property ample to cover the debt.
Unless volunturity advanced by Congress, not one dollar of loss can fall upon the Government, where the committee report six millions.
If the Government shall permit the earnings of the trains for 1861 to be applied to these outstanding acceptances, they will be paid off without recourse to the assignments.
Declarations Ot Mr. Benjamin.

It is charged that I promised Mr. Benjamin, a year or more ago, to issue no more acceptances.
I could not have made a promise to restrict my official discretion in a matter involving the existence of ten thousand people.
I simply expressed to Mr. Benjamin, as I would have expressed to any other gentleman, and friend, an intention to accept no more, which I entertained at the time.
The policy was always intended to be temporary, and was repeated simply because the necessities for doing so repeated themselves.
I could very easily have explained to Mr. Benjamin, or to the committee even, why the determination I had come to not to give further assistance was hanged.
The contractors had a claim against the Government amounting to a very large sum, as already shown.
It was believed that Congress would direct its payment.
If so, they would be in funds to execute the next season's work without help.-- The appropriation failed.
The season for transportation came on. Their embarrassments continued, and the credit of their contract, in an available form, became essential to them in order to enable them to supply the troops upon the plains.
For these reasons I again afforded them the assistance asked for.
The committee's own citations from Mr. Benjamin's testimony do not sustain the declarations to him which they put into my mouth.
The last acceptances.

I am charged with issuing acceptances in December to the exact amount of $870,000, that were put by Mr. Russell into the hands of Bailey.
For reasons already stated, I gave to Mr. Russell, during the money stringency of last fall, conditional acceptances to the amount of $643,000. At his request, I afterwards gave him another acceptance for $135,000. This amount made but $798,000. It was with old acceptances, given as far back as September and October, which he had not yet negotiated, that he made up the amount of $870,000 put into the hands of Bailey.
The supposed Results of protest.

Much is made of the fallacious supposition that, if the acceptances I gave these contractors had gone to protest, I should have been officially disgraced and have had to retire from the Cabinet The acceptances were legal, and were demanded by the interests of the public service.
The protest of them would have been annoying to me, and have subjected the transportation service to embarrassment; but further than that, the simple consequence would have been an order stopping the payments from the Quartermaster's Department to the contractors.
To suppose any graver consequence, was very egregiously to exaggerate the case.
Acceptances did go to protest in September, and I still remained in the Cabinet.
Thus the imputed object of the abstraction of the trust bonds proved to be fallacious; but still the abstraction went on. Yet it is upon the frall and foolish foundation of these totally imaginary consequences of protest to my reputation that the whole fabric of imputation is buill.
Mr. Drinkard's conversation with Mr. Bailey, expressing very gloomy views of the consequences of protest to my official standing, is prominently adduced by the committee.
I doubt not that Mr. Drinkard's convictions on the subject were sincere, imaginary as they were; but the fact that he took so exaggerated a view of the case proves that he could have had no conversation with me on the subject, and spoke wholly without my authority.
Mr. Bailey's connection with the Affair.

It must be borne in mind that during all the time, from July to December, whilst Mr. Bailey professes to have been moved by such a tender regard for my character, he never thought once of intimating to me what he was doing for its protection.
Besides this, the committee knew, or could have known by asking, that there was no sort of intimacy whatever between Mr. Bailey and myself; on the contrary, that our association was of the most formal kind.
I did not even know, until Mr. Bailey disclosed his defalcation to me in December last, that he occupied any special position of trust in the Interior Department.
I did not know that such bonds were in his custody, or even in the office of the Department.
There was not a soiltary circumstance between us of a sort which usually bind men together in bonds of friendship; no business connection, official or private; no association; no reason why Mr. Bailey should imperil his character and destroy his prospects in life forever for the purpe se of shiciding me from a danger which had no foundation.
A very high and noble motive was it certainly to risk his fame and reputation, and incur the risk of the penalties of a criminal act, to save a mere acquaintance, who had no earthly claim upon him, from an imaginary danger, and still more strange that he should not have thought it worth while to make the least inquiry about the subject, of the man he desired to serve.
Mr. Bailey's Confession.

Mr. Bailey's letter to me, dated the 19th of December, revealing the fact of the abstraction of the bonds, and his possession of the acceptances, bears upon its face, in every line and syllable, conclusive proof that he was revealing facts to me that he knew I was ignorant of. That was the whole subject — that was the sole object of his letter; written for any other object it would have been nousense.
No man on earth would have written such a letter as this unless to another ignorant of the subject disclosed, and so every honest man will decide.
Mr. Bailey, in this letter, asks for a personal interview with me before I should make any disclosures.
With this letter to me he sent a copy of his proposed letter to Mr. Thompson--in which he determined to conceal the transaction until the close of the Administration.
Immediately after his interview with me, which took place according to his request, he determined to disclose the transaction at once. If I had known anything of the abstraction, or had been implicated in the slightest degree in it, or felt any interest whatever in concealing it, how easy and natural would it have been for me to urge Mr. Bailey to persist in his plan of concealment?
And as, at that time, the committee assert, "Mr. Bailey, in the exercise of forethought prudent to avoid detection, made up his stock account for the year, showing on its face that the bonds were safe in his custody," nothing could have been more easy than to continue the concealment.
But immediately after this interview, Mr. Bailey changed his previously concerted plans, and made his disclosure.

Mr. Bailey does not leave the reason for this change of his plans in any doubt.
He said, in his conversations with various witnesses and others, " that he never would have changed his plans of concealment but for the conversation he held with me." I would not consent to become the depository of such a secret, and therefore Mr. Bailey concluded very properly that farther concealment was utterly impossible; and, consequently, on the very day of his interview with me, he directed Mr. Wagner to deliver his letter of confession to Mr. Thompson immediately on Mr. Thompson's return to the city.
It was not owing to Mr. Bailey's inability to arrange his coupon accounts with the Anditor to any extent, or in any part, that caused the "early disclosure;" this the committee knew perffectly well.
The committee knew that Mr. Bailey had gotten Mr. Thompson, the Secretary of the Interior, to certify that his accounts were ad correct, and that the bonds wore all in his possession at the very time when they had been abstracted.

In concluding, Mr. Floyd says that the whole investigation of the committee was carried on to convict him and not to investigate the truth of the charges, there not having been a single interrogatory put during the examination which was not designed to further that end. He adds:

If these facts, which neither malignity nor falsehood can overthrow or shake, are not enough to shield me against the cuckoo cry of frandulent contracts and countless embezzlements, it will be owing alone to the fact that Congress shall lend itself to the propagation of such reports as are the off spring of falsehood and malignity, instead of performing the high and noble duty of upholding the public interests by sustaining, or at least shielding from unjust assauit, those who have been faithful to their public trusts.

* As an instance of the committee's neglect or indisposition to bring out the whote truth, they have omitted to record the material fact that Mr. Thompson did give this certificate; which was filed on the 14th December.

div3.head:
The village Wonders.
[the Conclusion.]

p.q: " If it's a fair question, what pairt do ye live in, leddies? "

div3.p: We explained, with a similarly wide margin.

p.q:
"Ye'll have a gay time in the south.
Do ye go to many balls?"

" Not to balls.
Neither are we very gay-- we're too busy."
"Busy — what business have ye!"
"We are both eldest daughters, and that's a perfect labor in itself."
"What ye'll ca' labor — tooming the money out o' your purses upon counters, among silks, and velvets, and things."
"No, no, Mrs. Stewart, not that exactly."

"What kind o' queer letters are they ye had to-day frae hame?
Was yon your nanies?"

"No.
To amuse the village, we bade them just put on our initials."

div3.p:
She was called to the door by an inquisitive neighbor, who, of necessity, was marched in to criticise us, we bearing the inspection with the most unaffected artiessness.
Such was only a specimen of Mrs. Stewart's tactics; for to go through them all, and our answers, would make a tolerably well-sized volume.
"What ladies are these you have with you?" said the minister.

p.q: " dinna ken."
"What are their names at least?"
"I canna find oot, sir."
"Why don't you ask them?"
"They wanna tell."

div3.p: "That does not look well," said the minister; and he ever afterwards honored us with a broad scrutinizing stare, in right of his cloth.

Another person, smitten by the general curiosity, was a daft boy belonging to the village.
Everywhere we went, far or near, we saw him some time or other during the day-- No matter how early, or how privately we set out, he knew, and set out, too., Sometimes he would walk past us, and then sit down for a long time, and again overtake us. At first, we were a little alarmed and uncomfortable, but when we knew more about him, it only added to our amusement.
He never spoke once to us, and never pretended to notice us. No doubt the little spy greatly edified his mother and granny.

"Isn't it queer for a toun-body to look doun into a loch, when they're no accustomed t'it, and see the water wavin' away?" We were thus accosted by a most peculiar, smart, dark-eyed, elderly woman.
"Do ye like the Hielands?"

p.q:
"Ye'll hae seen near everything a'ready?
Ye'll hae been walkin' aboot a deal?"
"Yes, a good deal."
"Hiv ye seen the glen fa?"

"No.
Where is it?"

"Wad ye like to go?
I'm gaun there the noo. It's raal bonny."

div3.p: We assented.

p.q: "Ye'll be the leddies that's stoppin' doun at Mrs. Stewart's?"

div3.p: We acknowledged it.

p.q: "Div ye like her?"
"She is very kind and obliging."
"She's a fine body."

div3.p: "Is she your sister?" she whispered once to me, indicating Ally with her thumb.

p.q: "No; she is not my sister."
"Is she ony relation?"
"None in the world."
"What's her name?"
"I'm afraid you must ask her that yourself."
"What's your's, then?"
"It's such a long one, you could not pronounce it, and it is not worth trying to. "

div3.p: When we had seen the really beautiful falls, and were on level ground again, she turned to Ally: "What's your name now, miss?"

p.q: "People always forget names among these hills; I don't believe you could tell me your own, if I were to ask you!"

div3.p: With many a long screed of confidential gossip, she tried to tempt us to break our resolution, but in vain.
The lunkeeper "daundered" down also to Mrs. Stewart's once. "Have you never fund out your leddies' names?"

p.q: "Ne'er hae I. They winna tell me them, Jenny nor Jessamy, for a' my speerin' at them."
"I'm thinking they wadna hae been sae lang wi' me without my finding oot. Do they get hae letters?"

"Yes; but they hae jist some o' the A B C on them, 'Care o' ' the Postmaster." Such a daft-like thing.
It's one o' the things I dinna like aboot them, as if they couldna spell."
"I'm thinking they can do that richt weel."

"I ken that; for the postmaister shewed me twa letters they had addressed to Edinburgh to freends there, and a richt black dashin' hand they baith write; and they helpit me with my accounts the ither night, and richt grand figues they are, for certain."
"I'm thinking they're baith born ladies!"

"No — div ye?
Why !"

"Because Lord and Lady and Fitzbohn, they askit me the ither day what was their names, and I tell't them naebody could find oot. And they kind o' laughed, and Miss said: 'I've got a great fancy to find outmysel,' And I said: 'My lady, you'll find them any day you like by the loch-side, for they've begun sketches there,' And she and her mother did go, but I don't know what they said, only they bow to them now, when they meet them, and I heard Miss say: 'They are uncommon in everything'"

div3.p: Again:

p.q: "What kind o' lodgers are they ye have?"
"That's mair nor I can tell."

"Hoot, nonsense!
What'll be their names then?"

"I never was so beat in my life.
I askit the ane, and she said: 'We'll be like the Queen, add not tell our names till we go away' and when I speered at the ither ane, she says; 'What's in a name, Mrs. Stewart ! Peppermint by any ither name would smell as sweet.' But I never can be angry with them, however much I'm provoked at them.
We've gotten gey intimate noo; and I like them raal weel.
They've been twice butt at nichts wi' me warming theirsels at the fire, and they're rani cheery bodies."
"Why did ye no speer at them then?"

"Ay did I; but a' that I've fund oot is, that they were in Edinburgh before they cam here, and that maist o' their freends are there.
I've heard them speak o' this one's carriage and that one's carriage, and this hotel and that hotel, Sir This and Lady That, and Honorable Something Else; and they couldna hae kend thae folk unless they were gey stunnin' theirsels."

"I dinna believe in them.
What made them come here?"
"Jist to see the places, and learn to pent things frae natur.&"
"Daft-like leddies."

div3.p: "The Carry one says to me the ither day: Now, Mrs. Stewart, you must let me wash the tea-cups, and make the beds and sweep the floor, for it's such fun!" And I'm no thinkin' that if she'd been obliged to do it, she wad thocht it fun."

p.q: "Na, na; leddies wad hae brawer dresses!"

"Ay, but they're aye neat; and their dresses are made sae funny, like what my mither used to wear; and wil belts round their waists, like wee leddies.
But I suppose it maun be the fashion."

"Ony body can get the fashion in Edinburgh.
They'll be shopkeepers!"

"Ay, but onybody canna get beautiful goold watches.
And I had to wash some o' their linen, and it was sae bonny, wil dabbit holes worked a' round their things, and lace ayont it; and I've heard say that ye ken leddies by that mair than their out-dresses."
"If I were a leddy, I wad wear silks every day."

"And they've got initials on their letters, and is na that the thing only grand folk hae!
And the leddies at the hotel bow to them when they meet them!"

"They're no ken nae better!
But gude-bye the day. I dinna tak them for gospel, mind."

div3.p: A Highland lassie had been listening for some time to the conversation. "Sae ye havena fund oot their names yet?"

p.q: "No; and I'm no gaun to try it nae mair, for I'm tired o't, and I'm turnin' to like them, and winna bother them."
"They were doun the loch-side this morning again!"
"Ay, at their sketching; and beautiful sketches they make, the Ally ane best."

"Some folk said they werena canny; but dogs and bairns dinna tak to uncanny folk; and if ye saw oor Ruffler — every time he sees them far away, he flees like wnd, and'll hardly leave them; and they bring bits o' biscuits and bread to him. And Miss Robson up there says her dog Roy is the same, and he's a snappy thing.
Do ye think they're weel aff?"

"They maun be; or how could they hae come a' this distance for nae business.
And they're raal genteel wi' me. I'm sure I could cheat them, if I liket, but they dinna lose onything wi' being free.
And, forby, they're sae thankful to me for everything I do; it's a perfect pleasure.
They canna be accustomed to lodgings."

"I was raal glad that I cam in and saw them the ither nicht whan they were butt wi' you-- they're nice canty leddies, ony gate And if they're sae weel aff as ye think they are, I wish oor Donald wauld fa' across ane o' them, for he's every bit a gentleman barrin' the money, and that he canna win muckle o', for a' his hard wark at the tailorin'. Poor man, he's guid enough to be a marrow for onyhody!"
"Deed is he. He's a perfect jewel of a man!"

div3.p:
Thus was our past and future mapped out for us by the village — not that their guesses came near the truth.
Their ignorance was bliss; their ignorance was the mother of admiration.

The night before our departure, we were very confidential and friendly with Mrs. Stewart before her bright blazing fire.
We had been directing her how to forward our luggage, and gave her labels with the longcoveted names and addresses. "You see they are not much worth knowing, after all; But hasn't it been a good joke?
What a deal of fun and clatter it has given both the people and us!
What do they think of us?
Do they think we are cracked — or what?

"No.
How should I know?
We don't, I say"--

p.q:
"I understand.
But you know quite well that more than half of these Gaelic harangues were about us."

"Such nonsense.
Folk are sae conceited as to think we're speakin' o' them, when we talk in our mother-tongue."
"Maybe I know more of your mothertongue than you are aware of — so take care. "

"No!
Do ye?"

div3.p: "What do they say about us?

p.q: "They think ye're raal, fine, honest, sonsy lassies, o' the richt cut, and no feared for a Highland peatmoss."

"And I think they're quite correct; don't you?
Will you keep up the mystery about us when we're gone, for your private amusement?"

"Deed will
I."

"Town will be a great change to us, Mrs. Stewart.
Will you miss us?"

"Ay, won't I though!
And won't ye miss me and my ingle-cheek, and my bit crack?
ye'll no get the like in Edinburgh."

"No.
We won't get such fun again for a long time, for they keep us in trim order at home."
"Puir things!"
"But I'm so sleepy, and we're to be up so early — we must go."

div3.p: I drew out my watch.

p.q:
"What a fine watch!
Is it a motionless one?"

div3.p:
"No.
Listen!" and she examined it amid our hearty laughing.

p.q:
"Good night, Mrs. Stewart.
It't the last time we'll say that to you."

"Dlana break my heart, lassies.
I hope it'll pour rain like the mischief the morn! "

div3.p:
"That's not a kind wish, Mrs. Stewart, for we must leave in any weather.
Good-bye, in case we leave before you are up in the morning.

p.q: "Do you think I wad let ye leave my house without rising at ony hour to mak yer breakfasts?"

div3.p: And true enough Mrs. Stewart was up, though not usually an early riser; and when the inhabitants of the village were all astirring, "the nameless lassies" had vanished in the same mysterious manner as they had come.

I believe Mrs. Stewart kept up the talk a good while even after we left, for her own amusement.
They need it all, poor things; for I know that even when we were there, we heard them talk about the visitors of the preceding summer; and as to how long we would last them in that line, I cannot pretend to guess.
But as a secret when told is no secret, we won't tell it now, and let our readers make the most of it, as our Highland neighbors did.

Possession can be had on the 11th inst.
For terms, &c., apply to [ja 8--2awts] Peter Tinsley.

div3.head: Agricultural Fair grounds for rent.
div3.p:
--The Central Agricultural Society wish to rent out the Fair grounds for one year, or a term of years, reserving the right to hold Fairs and Cattle shows.
The tenant will be allowed the use of an excellent Brick House and the Saloons, with the privilege of cultivating, as a garden, ten acres of land, and using the Horse Track and Stables for a Trotting Park, subject to such regulations as the Executive Committee may prescribe, which will be made known before renting.
The rent must be paid quarterly, and bond, with good security, given for it. Apply to
de 25--ts James Lyons, Pres't.

J. H. Hartman, Dentist, having taken the office formerly occupied by Dr. Coulling, on Main, between 9th and 10th streets, Richmond, Va., is prepared to insert teeth from one to a complete set, and perform all other Dental Operations.
Having every facility requisite to the successful prosecution of his profession, he feels satisfied of giving perfect satisfaction to all who favor him with their patronage.
All work Warranted.
May be found at all hours, night and day mh 8--1m

Geo. B. Steel, Dentist, Office and residence South side of Main, between 7th and 8th streets, five doors above the Spotswood Hotel, Richmond, Va., performs all operations either in the operative or mechanical departments of Dentistry, in the best manner, using only the purest material.
fe 11--d1m

div3.head: Artificial Teeth.
div3.p:
--the Cheoplastic and Vulcanite Process.--G. W. Jones, Dentist, having the right for the above mode of making Teeth, and being satisfied of its absolute superiority over all other methods, can with confidence commend it to those desiring full or partial sets of teeth, and especially such as may be dissatisfied with those they are now using.--The perfect adaptation of the plate to the month, and the suction thereby secured, enables him to insert one or more teeth without clasps. This method having been adopted by those standing highest in the profession, North and South, testimonials will be given and specimens exhibited to those wishing to see them.
Sets of Teeth, on gold or any other plate, will, of course, be made for those preferring them.
Filling, Cleansing, Extracting, and all other operations gently and thoroughly performed.
Teeth extracted by Electricity, without pain.

Office on Main street, opposite Corinthian Hall.
